page.title: 08The Brick and Tile Industry
page.content: The old Kiln is a well-known landmark in Nettlebed which stands at the east end of the village behind the green.The industry was important to the village for several centuries, bricks and tiles made at Crocker End and Nettlebed were supplied to Stonor House and Wallingford Castle. Clay was mined from pits on the common to the north of the village and today ponds fill the remains of some old diggings. In 1677 Dr.Plot wrote of the strength of Nettlebed bricks - they could be tipped from a cart without breaking. Census records for 1881 tell us that at least a dozen men were working at either brickmaking or pottery producing tiles and earthenware pipes. The kiln was last used in 1938 when the industry died.
